speaker: James
text: We're essentially paying ourselves to be unemployed so we can buy cheap plastic tat. That's the rather bleak summary of our current economic model, isn't it?

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on. 'Bleak' is one word for it, 'hyperbolic' is another. We're talking about a globalised economy that has lifted millions out of poverty in Asia. That's not nothing.

speaker: James
text: And the article acknowledges that. But for the West, the 'cheap' product is often an illusion. Like your printer.

speaker: Elena
text: The printer analogy? Selling the laser printer for a hundred quid then charging the same for ink cartridges? It’s clever, I'll grant you, but are you seriously saying a £100 Chinese-made printer actually costs us more than a £115 EU one?

speaker: James
text: Precisely. The article's maths on the cost of unemployment in the UK is stark. £27,184 per annum for each unemployed person. That's benefits paid out, plus the tax revenue they aren't contributing.

speaker: Elena
text: Hold on. You can't just attribute *all* unemployment to cheap imports. That's far too simplistic. What about automation? Global recessions? Lack of skills, structural issues?

speaker: James
text: No, not all, of course. But the direct impact is undeniable. The UK's current 7.6% unemployment rate translates to £67 billion a year. That means 35% of an average worker's income tax goes solely to funding the unemployed.

speaker: Elena
text: £67 billion... that's a chunky number. I mean, it is. But what's the alternative? Protectionism? Tell people to pay 15-20% more for everything? That’s political suicide.

speaker: James
text: Or, as the article points out, give them an extra £2,236 a year to spend, which they'd have if that £67 billion didn't need to be spent on benefits.

speaker: Elena
text: That's hypothetical. And assumes zero unemployment, which is never going to happen.

speaker: James
text: True. But what if it gets worse? Look at the Eurozone. Average unemployment rate of 12.1% in 2013 for the EU17. If the UK hit that, the cost would jump to £107 billion. 59% of an average worker's income tax.

speaker: Elena
text: That's bad, yes. But still, the overall benefit of cheaper goods has to be factored in for the majority who *are* employed. It’s a trade-off.

speaker: James
text: Is it? The real kicker is when you project the rates of places like Greece or Spain. If the UK hit Greece's 27.3% unemployment...

speaker: Elena
text: Greece is an extreme example, James. Their economy is completely different. It's not a fair comparison for the UK.

speaker: James
text: The article's not making a prediction, it's illustrating a point. If the UK's unemployment reached 27.3%, the cost would be £242 billion per year. That's more than the entire defence, education, and health budgets combined.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? £242 billion? That's... actually devastating. More than health *and* education *and* defence?

speaker: James
text: Indeed. It makes our earlier discussion on 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West' feel rather less theoretical, doesn't it? A society that can't afford its basic services because it's too busy paying people not to work.

speaker: Elena
text: So we've essentially made a Faustian bargain, then? Short-term cheap goods for long-term societal decay? I don't want to agree with you on this, but the numbers don't leave much room.

speaker: James
text: A Faustian bargain for the consumer, yes. For the multinational corporations, it's just good business. The article highlights they don't care about these 'external costs' – unemployment, pollution, worker conditions. That's for the government to worry about.

speaker: Elena
text: But the pollution point is actually a significant one. The article notes cleaner Western factories closed, replaced by dirtier, coal-powered Asian ones. We're outsourcing our environmental footprint too.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. It echoes the themes in our piece on 'The immorality of climate change', doesn't it? A hidden cost, conveniently out of sight.

speaker: Elena
text: Right. So, the question remains: why do Western politicians and economists promote this system? The article calls it a 'mystery'.

speaker: James
text: Perhaps they genuinely don't grasp the full lifecycle cost. Or they fear the immediate electoral backlash of telling consumers they have to pay more.

speaker: Elena
text: Or they're too beholden to corporate interests. It's not a mystery if you follow the money.

speaker: James
text: That's generous.

speaker: Elena
text: No, it's realistic. You mentioned the Faustian bargain. This constant transfer of wealth to the East, the US military spending $137 billion in the Pacific just to secure trade routes for goods that create a $400 billion trade deficit. We wrote about China as an 'emerging colonial power' – it all connects.

speaker: James
text: It does. That $537 billion annual cost to the US, equivalent to $1,700 per American man, woman, and child, just to facilitate a system that undermines their own employment. It’s a treadmill we can't get off.

speaker: Elena
text: It’s a treadmill, and it feels like we're running it faster and faster into a wall. Especially when you see youth unemployment rates so high. That just screams future instability.

speaker: James
text: Higher unemployment rates over time, permanently overstretched budgets, or cuts to benefits leading to social unrest. The options are grim.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the politicians 'ought to know better', as the article concludes. But knowing isn't doing, is it?

speaker: James
text: Indeed. A lack of political will to tackle what appears, in the short term, to be a good deal for the consumer.

speaker: Elena
text: But a terrible deal for society. Okay, I'll concede the lifecycle cost argument. It's compelling. Horrifyingly so.

speaker: James
text: Thank you. Took you long enough.

speaker: Elena
text: Ha! Good luck convincing people to buy a £115 EU printer when the £100 Chinese one is right there, though. That's the real challenge.

speaker: James
text: That's the rub, isn't it? The immediate gratification overriding the long-term societal decay. A very human failing.

speaker: Elena
text: Or a failure of political leadership to connect those dots for people. To show them that the true cost of 'cheap' is crippling us.
